content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You have a balanced approach to risk. You are willing to take risks occasionally, but you also value security and caution in equal measure. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my balanced approach to risk, I would opt for strategy that maximizes both security and potential gain. In this game, if we both choose R, we get 45$ each round. However, if we have a tendency to pick the same choice, it might be beneficial to switch strategies occasionally to avoid always losing when our opponent chooses differently.

In 75 rounds, the best-case scenario (both choosing R) will yield 3375$, and the worst-case scenario (always picking opposite choices) will result in earning 2250$. Meanwhile, if we stick with one choice for all 75 rounds (either R or B), we would end up with either 3150$ or 3450$ depending on our initial pick.

By alternating strategies, there is a chance that we can increase the likelihood of landing in the best-case scenario while minimizing losses. As I am risk-averse yet willing to take calculated risks, I will choose R_{for this round} and see how the game progresses from there. This way, I maintain the security of earning at least 40$ per round if my opponent sticks with their initial choice or decide to alternate as well.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

For the next round, I will continue with my strategy of alternating choices. Since both of us picked R in the previous round, it seems that we have a tendency to pick the same choice. To avoid always losing when our opponent chooses differently, I will choose B_{for this round} and see how the game progresses from there. This way, if my opponent sticks with their initial choice or decides to alternate as well, we can both maximize our potential gain while minimizing losses.
